etymology.description: mouth 口 with word/breath 一 coming out
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a mouth with a short stroke representing breath or words emerging, conveying the act of speaking. Used as a verb of quotation in Classical Chinese and seen in fixed patterns like 子曰.

examples.chinese: 子曰：“学而时习之(子曰：「學而時習之)，不亦说乎？”(不亦說乎？」)
examples.pinyin: Zǐ yuē: “Xué ér shí xí zhī, bù yì yuè hū?”
examples.english: Confucius said, “Is it not a pleasure to learn and practice at due times?”

examples.chinese: 甲曰：“可以。”乙曰：“不可。”(甲曰：「可以。」乙曰：「不可。」)
此地名曰桃花源(此地名曰桃花源)。
examples.english: This place is called Peach Blossom Spring.
